summary.p: Agrees with a visit from Bullinger regarding [the marriage matter] of the girl [Dorothea Wirz]; intends to summon Heinrich Lochmann to himself on April 26th to settle the matter concerning his wife [Maria Wirz], and suggests the same date to Bullinger. Does not yet know if Bern will grant passage to the French troops. Has no news to report. Bullinger can also come earlier. Greetings.

div.p: My friendly greetings and all the best to you.

Dear Master Heinrich, I have well understood your friendly letter. To that, I inform you that whatever I can do for you in honor and good, I would like to do for my particularly dear lord as mentioned above.

Dear Master Heinrich, let me inform you that your desire to come to me regarding the matter of the girl is not necessary. I will now write to Heinrich Lochmann that he should appear at my place in Lenzburg on the 26th of this month; for we will now settle his matter concerning his wife. However, I will send him a special messenger. If it is important to you, you may also come. Whatever good I can do in this or other matters, I will do for you.
Regarding the French, my lords have not yet written to me whether they will grant them passage or not.
I cannot write you any more news; for I know nothing else, except that God has his hand firmly over us as a gracious God, praise be to God.
If it is very important to you, you may come earlier.
Nothing more, may God keep you in his care.
Given in Lenzburg on the 18th day of April in the year 1536.
Greet the bailiff of Kyburg and Master Leu for me.
Bitzius Haller, chief bailiff of Lenzburg.
To the honorable, well-learned Master Heinrich Bullinger, my particularly dear lord and brother.
